CheckList.name: Healthy Home Quiz
CheckList.checkListInfo: Use the Healthy Home Quiz to check the health of your home, identify assets and challenges. Use the Tips to minimize indoor pollutants and create a home that promotes wellbeing.

Question.questionText: Is your home located next to a busy road or business where cars idle?
Question.questionInfo:
If you live on a busy road or where cars idle you are likely to be subjected to higher levels of motor vehicle pollutants.

Motor vehicles emit exhaust gases into the air such as carbon monoxide, oxides of nitrogen, hydrocarbons and particulates, along with evaporative emission otherwise known as fuel vapours.

An Australian EPA (Environmental Protection Agency) study (EPA Publication 789) found a link between high levels of fine particles, ozone, nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide and an increase in the number of hospital admissions for respiratory and cardiovascular disease.

If opening your windows subjects you to these fumes you may like to opt for an air purifier to assist you to keep your indoor air clean.

Question.questionText: Do you use chemical pesticides around the exterior of the house or garden?
Question.questionInfo:
Let's state the obvious - pesticides are designed to kill pests!

Many pesticides can also pose a risk to human health. In some instances you will not find ingredients listed on the product label as the manufacturer may be protecting their secret formula. But this means you don't really know what chemicals you are using in your home. Just because a product is being sold does not mean it is safe.

In many countries products such as these are not tested for human health.

Children are more susceptible to pesticides given their size and there is much documented about the connection between pesticides and health issues.

We like the work of Pesticides.org - http://www.pesticides.org/docs/website-home-use.pdf

Question.questionText: Do you have any asbestos around the home - exterior cladding, interior cladding, interior tiles, eaves, in heaters, on your shed or garage?
Question.questionInfo:
If you are unsure whether your home contains asbestos - we strongly suggest you contact a local licensed asbestos assessor to provide a report of asbestos located on your property.

Avoid disturbing asbestos where possible. If removal is necessary, we recommend using a licensed asbestos contractor who will remove and dispose of it safely to avoid harming others.

Asbestos exposure can be fatal years after exposure. Asbestos has been named a carcinogen in many countries.

For more information relevant to your area contact your local building authority.

Some general information can be found at http://www.asbestos.act.gov.au/about_asbestos.

Question.questionText: Is there evidence of mould around the outside of the house?
Question.questionInfo:
Mould around the exterior of the house can impact on the interior materials and quality of air inside the home.

Check that land drainage is adequate, that spouting and down pipes are in good working order and there are no cracks or holes in the roof or wall structures. Excess moisture around the home can lead to mould growth and material deterioration.

Preventing problems early will save you money and prevent mould growth that may impact on your health.

Question.questionText: Has your home been freshly painted within the last 2 years?
Question.questionInfo:
Freshly painted surfaces are higher in VOCs in the period of time directly after painting. The level of VOCs emitted from paintwork in the home will depend on the type of paint.

Consider opting for low VOC or No VOC brands when choosing paint. You can choose from plant based paints or petroleum based paints. If choosing a petroleum based paint, water based paints are healthier options rather than solvent based paints.

If starting a painting project it's a good idea to keep children out of freshly painted areas for the first few weeks while the space is aired out and until the highest levels of VOCs have dissipated.

Question.questionText: Do you have any plasticised wall paper on your walls?
Question.questionInfo:
Plasticised wallpapers may contain PVC that contains volatile organic compounds (VOCs) that off-gas. PVC also contains phthalate chemicals that are found in plastics. Some phthalate chemicals have been found to migrate into household dust and have been linked to asthma.

Opt for paper based wallpaper or fabrics such as linen, silk, sisal, or jute with a water based low VOC adhesive.

Question.questionText: Are any of your walls made from asbestos sheeting?
Question.questionInfo:
Asbestos is known to cause serious health problems. Asbestos was used to create various products used in housing prior to the mid 1980's and may still be used in some countries. Asbestos sheeting was used for many purposes, often for wet area surfaces hidden behind tiles, for walls, or eaves around a house.

Asbestos contains small particles that if disturbed can cause serious health problems. Have an asbestos audit done on your home and ensure that asbestos is safely removed by a specialist.

Asbestos was also used for many other products and should be avoided or treated with caution.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asbestos

http://www.asbestosadvisor.net/What_does_asbestos_look_like.aspx

Question.questionText: Is there cracked and peeling paint on any of the walls?
Question.questionInfo:
Houses painted before 1970 in Australia may have been painted with paint containing high levels of lead. Modern household paints contain less than 1% lead, however renovating or repairing old paint surfaces can expose lead from old paint and can contaminate surfaces and cause lead poisoning.

Small amounts of lead can cause serious health problems particularly for children. Lead has been associated with a wide range of health issues such as behavioural, growth and cognitive issues in children and nervous system, cardiovascular and kidney health issues among others for adults.

Purchase a lead test kit from the local hardware store and test if your old paintwork contains lead before you disturb it. Lead is only a danger once disturbed. Consider repainting the substrate without disturbing the original surface or replace the substrate or hire a professional to remove the lead paint safely.

Refer to the 6 step guide to painting your home - http://www.environment.gov.au/atmosphere/airquality/publications/leadpaint.html

Question.questionText: Do you have vinyl floor coverings that are in poor condition?
Question.questionInfo:
A study of phthalates in indoor dust and their association with building characteristics by Gustaf Bornehag and others published by Environment Health Perspectives found a dose response relationship between concentrations of phthalates (plastic softeners) in bedroom dust and the likelihood of being diagnosed with asthma, rhinitis or eczema.

Studies suggest that plastic softeners can find their way into household dust and be inadvertently inhaled.

Opting for products free from plastics is a safer alternative for people and the environment.

For more information on asthma see - http://www.asthma.org.au/Resources.aspx

Question.questionText: Can you see any mould on any of the walls or ceiling in your home?
Question.questionInfo:
Mould can cause a range of health issues such as fatigue, weakened immune system and contribute to allergy symptoms.

Mould in the home indicates a problem with moisture and could be a result of a structural problem such as leaks, poor drainage, flooding, rising damp, condensation or humidity. Removing and preventing mould will assist with minimising maintenance expenses but importantly will prevent mould spores from growing and impacting on indoor air quality and your health.

When moulds are disturbed they release spores into the air, so while cleaning mould ensure you wear a suitable face mask. To clean mould use an 80% naturally fermented white vinegar to 20% water solution.

http://www.mould.com.au/mythsaboutmould.htm

Question.questionText: Do your windows open and close properly?
Question.questionInfo:
Opening windows can assist with reducing indoor air pollution that has accumulated from building materials and finishes, furniture, household items and lifestyle practices.

According to a 2012 report by leading global interdisciplinary design firm Perkins+Will, 374 substances that may be found in the home environment were highlighted as known or suspected asthmagens.

Question.questionText: Are window and door screens in good repair?
Question.questionInfo: Opening doors and windows regularly helps with ventilation, pushing stale and often polluted indoor air out.

Question.questionText: Is there cracked or peeling paint around the windows?
Question.questionInfo:
Old houses may have been painted with paint containing lead. If paintwork is deteriorated chemicals from paintwork are more likely to find their way into household dust that may inadvertently be inhaled or ingested.

Buy a lead test kit from the hardware store before undertaking any DIY repair work as lead paintwork needs to be repaired using protection.

Use a HEPA filter vacuum regularly to minimise the spread of dust throughout the house.

Question.questionText: When raining, does water enter windows when they are closed?
Question.questionInfo: Mould needs moisture to start growing - prompt maintenance to repair the water leaks is needed now!

Question.questionText: Do you have plasticised window coverings such as blinds or curtains?
Question.questionInfo:
When heated plastics release VOCs (volatile organic compounds), better known as gases or fumes.

Plasticised window coverings receive direct sunlight and heat up in the window and contribute to poor indoor air quality. Some plasticised fabrics can contain phthalate chemicals (plastic softeners) that have been found to migrate into household dust and linked with health concerns.

Opt for window furnishings free from plastics. Natural fibres or naturally treated timber are a great option.

Question.questionText: Do you use a HEPA vacuum cleaner to remove dust from your house?
Question.questionInfo:
HEPA stands for High-Efficiency Particulate Air. A HEPA filter is a type of mechanical air filter that works by forcing air through a fine mesh filter that traps harmful particles.

A HEPA filter vacuum used to clean the home minimises the spread of household dust that may be polluted with chemicals that have migrated from household products, as well as eliminating pollens, pet dander and dust mites.

Question.questionText: Do you have fluorescent lighting in your home?
Question.questionInfo:
Compact fluorescent lighting generally contains mercury. When fluorescent lighting is broken, mercury vapour is released into the air and has been linked to health concerns.

The long life and low power consumption of these lamps tends to make them a popular choice for homeowners.

Opt for maximising natural lighting within a home through the use of windows strategically placed to gain maximum sunlight or installation of skylights (roof windows). LED lighting is an energy efficient option for those seeking an alternative energy efficient lighting alternative.

If you break a fluorescent lamp within the home, this should be disposed of with care. You can find more information here - http://www2.epa.gov/cfl/cleaning-broken-cfl

Question.questionText: Have you investigated Radon levels in your home?
Question.questionInfo:
Radon is a colorless, odorless, radioactive gas. It forms naturally from the decay of radioactive elements, such as uranium, which can be found at different levels in soil and rock throughout the world.

Radon gas in the soil and rock can move into the air and into homes and has been associated with lung cancer. Different locations around the world have differing levels of Radon.

You can check radon levels in your home to determine if you need to take action. Do-it-yourself radon detection kits can be ordered through the mail or purchased in some hardware stores. The kits are placed in the home for a period of time and then mailed to a lab for analysis.

Read more about Radon and health concerns - http://www.who.int/ionizing_radiation/env/radon/en/

World Health Organisations Handbook on indoor Radon - http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2009/9789241547673_eng.pdf

Question.questionText: Do you have a door mat?
Question.questionInfo:
Door mats assist to trap unwanted particles from entering the home and accumulating in household dust.

The dust within our homes gets circulated by movement of occupants, heating and cooling systems.

What is even better than a door mat? Have shoes taken off at the front door!

Question.questionText: Do you take your shoes off when entering the house?
Question.questionInfo:
Taking shoes off at the front door prevents germs, bacteria, chemical residues and heavy metals from being walked into the home.

Young children have lots of hand to mouth action and pollutants can be easily ingested from surfaces.

Question.questionText: Upon entering the house do you smell fragrances, eg. air fresheners, incense or candles?
Question.questionInfo: Avoid air fresheners, petro chemically produced candles and incense - opt for natural essential oils, plants or flowers.

Question.questionText: Do you smell a musty, damp mould smell?
Question.questionInfo: A damp, musty smell indicates that moisture is accumulating somewhere it should not be.

Question.questionText: While walking around the house can you smell cleaning products?
Question.questionInfo:
Many cleaning products do not list all their ingredients on the label and can contain chemicals that are considered toxic.

Cleaning products leave residues on surfaces around the home creating opportunities for chemicals to be absorbed through the skin, inhaled or ingested.

A clean odour can have "no" odour.

Question.questionText: Do you have plastic in or around your bed, eg. plasticised fabric on the bed frame or plasticised mattress protector?
Question.questionInfo:
In addition to releasing VOCs, plastics can contain phthalates, otherwise known as plastic softeners. Some phthalates have been found to migrate into household dust and been linked to endocrine altering health issues and allergies.

A Study by Bornehag CG etal titled "The Association between Asthma and Allergic Symptoms in Children and Phthalates in House Dust" showed that "phthalates, within the range of what is normally found in indoor environments, are associated with allergic symptoms in children".

Opt for natural fibre fabrics such as hemp, cotton, linen and wool. Mattress protectors made from organic cotton or wool are great options.

Read more - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15471731

Question.questionText: Do you have a mattress that has been treated with a chemical flame retardant?
Question.questionInfo:
Some flame retardant chemicals have been found to migrate into household dust and have been linked to a host of health concerns relating to nervous system health, hormonal and thyroid function health among others.

Read more :
http://www.ewg.org/release/new-research-finds-highly-toxic-flame-retardants-widespread-homes-furniture
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flame_retardant

Question.questionText: Do you have a mattress that has been treated with a chemical stain guard treatment?
Question.questionInfo:
Perfluorinated chemicals (PFCs) are widely-used water, grease and stain repellents. PFCs have been associated with health concerns such as immune suppression, reproductive problems and hormonal disorders.

PFCs can be found in carpets and furnishings as well as non-stick food packaging.

Opt for products that have not been chemically treated.

Question.questionText: Are you sleeping on a foam mattress?
Question.questionInfo:
Foams are made from petrochemicals that can offgass into the air that you breathe while sleeping, and many foams contain flame retardant chemicals.

Choose a mattress made from untreated, non-toxic natural materials containing no synthetic chemicals or fire retardants. Opt for a mattress made from natural fibres with NO chemical treatments.

If a new mattress is not an option buy a wool and organic cotton mattress topper.

Question.questionText: Do you have unsealed particle board or MDF furniture in your bedroom?
Question.questionInfo:
The adhesives used to make particle board and MDF (medium density fibreboard) often contain urea formaldehyde.

Formaldehyde can offgass into indoor air. Formaldehyde has been documented to contribute to eye, nose, and throat irritation; wheezing and coughing; fatigue, skin rashes among other more serious health conditions.

Opt for solid timber, metal or glass furniture.

Read more - http://www.epa.gov/iaq/formaldehyde.html

Question.questionText: Do you have synthetic carpets in your bedroom?
Question.questionInfo:
Toxic chemicals can be found in fibre bonding materials, backing glues, fire retardants, dyes, fungicides and stain resistant treatments.

Opt for carpets made from natural fibres such as wool, sisal, coir or seagrass to minimise VOCs. Avoid chemical treatments such as stain resistance, mothproofing and fungicides. Carpets with woven or jute backing are preferable to rubberised options.

Read more - http://www.epa.gov/iaq/voc.html

Question.questionText: Do you use organic bed sheets?
Question.questionInfo:
Opt for organic bedding that is produced in accordance with Global Organic Textile Standards where possible. If this is not possible try to buy bed sheets that are Okeo-Tex Certified.

Avoid textiles that have been chemically treated such as stain resistant, crease free and antibacterial chemical treatments.

Question.questionText: Do you dry clean your clothes, blankets or other items?
Question.questionInfo:
Tetrachloroethene is a toxic chemical that is widely used in the dry-cleaning of fabrics. Other names for tetrachloroethene include PERC, tetrachloroethylene, perchloroethylene or PCE.

PERC can contribute to poor indoor air quality and for those with skin sensitivities can contribute to allergy symptoms.

Opt for PERC free cleaning methods such as steam cleaning or hand washing of items. If dry cleaning is necessary, hang the item outdoors until the odour is gone.

Read more - http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/tfacts18.pdf

Question.questionText: Is there air flow under your mattress / bed?
Question.questionInfo:
Unobstructed space under a mattress encourages air flow circulation and discourages moisture build up in the mattress.

A bed design with slatted timber supports works well as long as the space under the mattress is free from clutter.

Question.questionText: Do you have sufficient concealed storage in your bedroom?
Question.questionInfo:
Minimising dust in the bedroom helps to promote good indoor air quality for optimal health, as dust can circulate with movement, heating and cooling. Dust can contribute to allergies and asthma.

Creating storage that is concealed prevents surface dust from collecting on items over time. Opt for shelving with doors, storage boxes with lids and minimise clutter.

Question.questionText: Do you open the window in your bedroom weekly?
Question.questionInfo:
Research has shown that air inside the home is often many times more polluted than the air outside the home.

Opening windows regularly will assist to flush out the build-up of VOCs that have accumulated in the indoor air. Even in cooler months a quick burst of outdoor air can help to maintain healthier indoor air for our lungs.

Question.questionText: Do you sleep next to a clock radio or have any other electrical device turned on nearby, eg. electric blanket?
Question.questionInfo:
Could your bedroom design be preventing you from having a restful sleep due to Electromagnetic Fields (EMFs).

The issue of EMFs is receiving increasing attention globally in relation to health concerns and health sensitivities. Many hours are spent sleeping. Eliminating sources in the bedroom is a precautionary approach to ensure you get a healthy, good nights sleep.

Remove electrical devices from the bedroom, avoid metal bed frames and mattresses with metal as metal tends to intensify electromagnetic fields.

Are there appliances on walls adjoining the bedroom?

Keep beds away from appliances on adjoining walls.

Demand switches and other shielding options are available for those who wish to take further action.

You may like to read more about this contentious issue here - http://www.magdahavas.com/

Question.questionText: Do you have a good exhaust fan over the cooking area?
Question.questionInfo:
The tissue test is a cheap and easy way to test if you have good air extraction from your exhaust fan. Hold a ½ ply tissue a few centimetres away from the vent. When the fan is on does it draw the tissue up to the vent easily?

Effective extraction of cooking gasses helps to minimise combustion pollutants that can build up in your indoor air. Combustion pollutants have been linked to health issues.

Question.questionText: Are there any signs of mould or mildew in the kitchen, including under the sink?
Question.questionInfo:
"Occupants of damp or mouldy buildings are at increased risk of experiencing health problems such as respiratory symptoms, respiratory infections, allergic rhinitis and asthma."

Identify and eliminate the source of moisture. There are various ways to clean mould - we like the 80% naturally fermented white vinegar solution with 20% water.

Read more - http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0003/78636/Damp_Mould_Brochure.pdf

Question.questionText: Do you use non-stick cooking items, eg. pots and pans?
Question.questionInfo:
Perfluorchemicals (PFCs) are commonly used to create non-stick cookware. There is growing concern and information available that PFCs are highly toxic.

Opt for stainless steel, cast iron or glass cookware.

Read more - http://www.healthybuilding.net/healthcare/2009-04-20PFCs_fact_sheet.pdf

Question.questionText: Do you use antibacterial hand or dish soap?
Question.questionInfo:
Tricolsan is a chemical found in many consumer products including many antibacterial soaps and liquids. According to the Environmental Working group Triclosan has been "linked to liver and inhalation toxicity, and low levels of triclosan may disrupt thyroid function."

Opt for soaps that use natural ingredients and look for ingredients that you can understand on the label.

Question.questionText: Are the garbage recycling and any compost bins covered?
Question.questionInfo:
Pests like food, moisture and shelter and an open recycling bin is the perfect home.

Keep bins covered to avoid attracting pests. Pests can create a mess, multiple and spread germs.

Question.questionText: Are there any signs of pests, eg. droppings or moths, in the kitchen?
Question.questionInfo:
Clean up spills quickly and keep surfaces such as bench tops and inside cupboards clean. To minimise the temptation to pests ensure bins are sealed, containers used to store food are kept closed and screens on windows and doors are in good working order.

If you must use a product to help rid your home of pests opt for chemical free options such as physical traps or non-toxic applications.

Question.questionText: Do you have a carbon monoxide detector in the kitchen?
Question.questionInfo:
Carbon monoxide detectors are reasonably inexpensive and may help you detect a gas leak.

Carbon Monoxide known as CO is found in combustion fumes such as those from stoves, gas cooking, gas heating and engine fumes. CO can build up in enclosed spaces without an odour and can cause poisoning.

Common symptoms associated with CO poisoning is headaches, weakness, nausea, vomiting, confusion and chest pain. High levels of Carbon Monoxide can cause loss of consciousness and death.

Detectors help keep your home safe and alert you to any CO leaks.

Question.questionText: Do you use plastic containers to store your food?
Question.questionInfo:
Plastics contain plastic softeners known as phthalates. Phthalates have been known to migrate into food sources while food is being stored. Some phthalates have been linked to hormone disruption health concerns.

Opt for alternatives such as glass, stainless steel or ceramic storage containers.

Question.questionText: Do you use plastic in the microwave?
Question.questionInfo:
Plastics should not be heated, especially near food as chemicals can migrate into the food.

DEHP is a phthalate (plastic softener) found in some plastics and can particularly migrate into fatty food when heated.

Avoid using plastic in the microwave.

Question.questionText: Do you drink or eat from pottery items?
Question.questionInfo:
Use ceramic cookware from large reputable suppliers.

Look at the label to see if the item guarantees it is lead free. Lead can be used in the glazing process of ceramics and if ingested is harmful. Lead test kits can be purchased from the hardware store.

Don't use old glazed ware for cooking, keep these as decorative items. Wash ceramic cookware by hand and if you notice cracks or chipping replace the item.

Question.questionText: Do you check the containers you buy your food in - do they have the plastic ID numbers 3,6 or 7 ?
Question.questionInfo:
Get to know your plastics by checking your food packaging for a small triangle indicating the type of plastic.

Numbers 3, 6 and 7 have been associated with hormone disrupting chemicals. Hormone disrupting chemicals have been linked to early puberty, obesity, development disorders, diabetes and cancer.

Read more at the plastics pocket guide - http://www.ecocycle.org/files/pdfs/pocket_guide_singleprint.pdf

Question.questionText: Do you choose organic or pesticide free food options?
Question.questionInfo:
Organic food can be expensive. If you are not able to eat organic produce make sure you wash your fresh produce well to remove any pesticide, fungicide or herbicide residue.

A solution of 10% vinegar with 90% water can be used to soak vegetables and fruit before rinsing to help remove contaminants.

Question.questionText: Do you eat canned goods?
Question.questionInfo:
Many canning companies are placing a lining inside cans that contains Bisphenol A, otherwise known as BPA.

BPA has been linked to hormonal disruption health concerns. Studies have found that BPA can migrate into the canned food which is then eaten. Given the concern over BPA some companies are using a BPA alternative known as Bisphenol S (BPS), however there is concern mounting that this alternative may also not be safe.

Opt for fresh or frozen food instead.

Question.questionText: Do you use plastic drinking bottles?
Question.questionInfo: To avoid potential plastic softeners from leaching into your beverage opt for stainless steel water bottles free from any internal lining.

Question.questionText: Do you filter your drinking water?
Question.questionInfo:
Water supplies around the world vary greatly as does the type of treatment given to public water supplies. Using a water filter can remove bacteria, pesticides, lead, copper, iron, chlorine, nitrates and fluoride (depending on the filter used).

Clean water is essential for good health. In instances where family members have skin conditions removing harsh irritants such as chlorine can also be beneficial.

Question.questionText: Is there a musty mould smell in the bathroom?
Question.questionInfo:
Safely remove the mould and fix the cause.

Tips to avoiding mould in the bathroom are:

  • Shorter, cooler showers minimises the build-up of steam
  • Use a ceiling exhaust fan during and shortly after showering to remove steam and help dehumidify the air
  • If the bathroom has a window keep it open when possible for air circulation
  • Wipe down wet surfaces after finishing in the bathroom
  • Clean the bathroom regularly to avoid mould growth
  • Hang towels where they will dry as wet towels in a bathroom all day create a damp environment.

Question.questionText: Do you see any signs of water damage?
Question.questionInfo:
Mould thrives in damp areas. A common area for mould growth in the bathroom is under silicone sealant around tiles. Remove the sealant, clean the area well, ensure it is dry and then reseal with a wet area low VOC sealant.

Tea tree oil is effective in cleaning mould. A 3% solution or 2 teaspoons in a spray bottle with 2 cups of water (shake well) can be used as an alternative to a vinegar solution.

Question.questionText: Does water condense on the inside of the window?
Question.questionInfo:
Condensation is a common cause of dampness in buildings, often occurring on cold walls, windows and floors, but it can also occur in roof spaces and in sub-floor areas.

To minimise condensation increase ventilation by using fans for air circulation or opening a window.

In cooler months indoor temperature throughout the home should ideally be kept at a constant even temperature to warm surfaces.

Insulate cold surfaces.

Remove moisture sources such as drying wet clothes indoors.

Install a dehumidifier if required.

Question.questionText: Is there a working exhaust fan over the shower?
Question.questionInfo:
The tissue test is a cheap and easy way to test if you have good air extraction from your exhaust fan.

Hold a ½ ply tissue a few centimetres away from the vent. When the fan is on does it draw the tissue up to the vent easily?

Install a closure device to the top of your exhaust fan that only opens when in use to prevent heat loss and pest access.

Question.questionText: Do you have a plastic or PVC shower curtain?
Question.questionInfo:
A Study by the Center for Health, Environment & Justice (USA) found PVC shower curtains can release as many as 108 volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the air.

Opt for PVC-free shower curtains made out of safer materials such as organic cotton, nylon, polyester.

Read more at - http://www.chej.org/showercurtainreport/documents/Volatile%20Vinyl%20Executive%20Summary.pdf

Question.questionText: Do you use antibacterial hand soap?
Question.questionInfo:
Triclosan is an anti-bacterial chemical used in many anti-bacterial soaps and products.

Tricolan has been linked to liver, thyroid and endocrine (hormone development) disorders in children.

The over use of antibacterial products may lead to germs becoming immune to them and develop into superbugs that are not easily treated with antibiotics.

See how the World Health Organisation says you get clean hands - http://www.who.int/gpsc/clean_hands_protection/en/

Question.questionText: Do you use non-toxic, natural ingredient hair products?
Question.questionInfo:
What we use to wash our hair with impacts on our skin and can be irritating.

Avoid Sodium Lauryl Sulphate which is a widely used synthetic detergent found in many personal items.

Check out David Suzuki's dirty dozen guide - http://davidsuzuki.org/dirty12/#wrapper

Question.questionText: Do you use non-toxic, natural ingredient personal care products?
Question.questionInfo:
Have you read the label - do you really know what you are using?

Your skin is your bodies largest organ and is capable of absorbing products used.

Did you know that formaldehyde is used in many personal care products?

Did you know that formaldehyde is classified a probable carcinogen?

Opt for products made from natural organic ingredients where possible.

Look for products that are independently certified.

Look for companies that are transparent with their ingredients.

For more tips about personal care products visit the Environmental Working Group Skin Deep database - http://www.ewg.org/skindeep

We love the transparent, organic, independently certified natural products by Miessence, check them out here - http://www.miessence.com

Question.questionText: Do you use non-toxic, washing products?
Question.questionInfo:
Many ingredients used to create washing powders are not mentioned on the product label and are untested for human health.

Harsh washing powders can irritate the skin. Fabric softeners and scented drying products made from toxic chemicals subtly coat washing. Synthetic fragrances are among the world's top allergens and are suspected of being endocrine disruptors.

Opt for products with NO synthetic surfactants, no artificial fragrance, no bulking agents or fillers.

Question.questionText: Does water condense on the walls and ceilings when using appliances in the laundry?
Question.questionInfo: Efficient ventilation and an exhaust fan is needed in the laundry to prevent moisture damaging the laundry room or making its way into other rooms of the house and encouraging mould growth.

Question.questionText: Is your clothes dryer vented to the outside of the house?
Question.questionInfo:
Venting the air externally will prevent excess moisture indoors. If the unit is not vented it may cause condensation and encourage mould growth. Venting into the roof cavity can also cause moisture issues to insulation and building materials.

Opt for external release of moisture sources where possible.

Question.questionText: Do you store paints and garage related products in your laundry?
Question.questionInfo:
Products can offgass while being stored.

Keep paints, coatings and chemicals safely stored outside the house to avoid off gassing and polluting indoor air.

Question.questionText: Do you dry clean your clothes?
Question.questionInfo:
Tetrachloroethylene is often used in the dry-cleaning process and this chemical is classed a category 3 carcinogen and has been documented as having the potential to cause skin irritation.

If dry cleaning is necessary, hang dry cleaned clothes outside for a while after collecting to minimise the fumes before putting them away indoors.

Question.questionText: Do you use microfiber cloths for dusting?
Question.questionInfo:
Microfibre clothes attract dust to the cloth surface and reduce dust from being airborne.

Many household chemicals migrate into dust such as flame retardants, stain resistant and insecticide chemicals.

Question.questionText: Do you use a HEPA vacuum filter?
Question.questionInfo:
HEPA stands for High Efficiency Particulate Air filter.

Air and dust is forced through a fine mesh filter trapping small particles of dust, pollens, pet dander and other pollutants to prevent them from being circulated when cleaning and therefore assists with the quality of your indoor air.

Question.questionText: Do you use environmentally friendly cleaning products?
Question.questionInfo:
Look for manufacturers who list ALL their ingredients on the label.

Contact the consumer number on the label and ask for a copy of the Material Safety Data Sheet so you understand what you are using and the hazards.

Question.questionText: Do you ask guests to take their shoes off at the door?
Question.questionInfo:
Put a large door mat outside doors.

People walk all sorts of pollutants such as pesticides, heavy metals and germs indoors via dust on their shoes.

Question.questionText: Do you use fragrance products inside the home, eg. stand-alone scents, plug ins?
Question.questionInfo:
Synthetic fragrances are one of the world's top allergens and are also suspected of being endocrine disruptors.

Opt for natural fragrances such as flowers.

Question.questionText: Do you leave your car idling in the driveway?
Question.questionInfo:
Exhaust fumes can potentially contain carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, benzenes, sulphur dioxide, lead, formaldehyde and particulate matter.

Vehicle emissions are toxic and can make their way indoors if stationery for extended periods of time.

Question.questionText: Do you use an open fire in your home?
Question.questionInfo: Wood smoke is a mixture of gasses and particles that are airborne. Wood smoke has been documented by many organisations as impacting on human health particularly on susceptible people such as those with heart and lung disease, asthma and small children.

Question.questionText: Do you have indoor plants?
Question.questionInfo:
A study by NASA has shown that indoor house plants have been shown to remove various toxins from indoor air such as formaldehyde, benzene, xylene among others.

To learn more about the type of plants studied read "How to Grow Fresh Air" available here - http://www.healthyinteriors.com.au/shop/products/great-books/

Question.questionText: Does anyone smoke indoors?
Question.questionInfo:
Tobacco smoke will pollute indoor air and has been shown to cause cancer.

A healthy family is a great reason to give up or ask visitors to smoke outdoors away from windows and doors to prevent smoke entering the house.

Question.questionText: Do you spray pesticides in the house or use pest free plug ins?
Question.questionInfo:
Airborne pesticide products pollute indoor air and can potentially be inhaled.

Opt for natural pest remedies where possible or physical type baits or traps that do not spread chemicals throughout the home.
